title: High Street UK 2020: Transferring knowledge to facilitate the repositioning, reinventing, rebranding and restructuring of sustainable retail centres.
abstractText:
The High Street UK 2020 project will support high street change through knowledge exchange. The project will connect key high street stakeholders (retailers, town centre partnerships, local authorities, property owners/developers and residents) in 10 locations (Alsager, Altrincham, Ballymena, Barnsley, Bristol, Congelton, Holmfirth, Market Rasen, Morley and Wrexham) with the knowledge and intelligence they need to deliver a sustainable high street in 2020. Project objectives include:

 

  • completing a state-of-the art review of major factors that contribute to retail centre change
  • identifying a hierarchy of effects in retail and retail centre change, using the literature review and a panel of retail and spatial experts
  • developing the High Street UK model of retail centre change
  • enabling user communities to forecast retail centre change in their specific retail location, using the High Street UK forecasting model 
  • building a Framework for High Street Intervention with four main components of 'repositioning', 'reinventing', 'rebranding' and 'restructuring' based on the management and marketing literature
  • developing a series of sustainable centre plans (based on the Framework for High Street Intervention) with the 10 partner locations
  • sharing a suite of legacy products, such as the modelling tool, podcasts from academic experts and a special issue of the Journal of Place Management and Development.
impactText: Findings have been used to prirotise town centre decision making and action in all 10 towns. Findings have influenced the restructuring of governance partnerships, to the delivery of social media marketing campaigns. findingsText: We have reviewed over 200 published studies, and employed a consensus building scoring method with UK retail experts, to quantify the influence of over 200 factors on the vitality and viability of the High Street. For the first time local partnerships have access to information to enable them to prioritise their action and resources towards interventions they can initiate that will improve footfall. Any town, city or district partnership can use our model to identify priority action areas that will make a difference to the vitality and viability of their retail area.
